segment.source: Advanced security auditing FAQ (Windows 10)
segment.target: Advanced security auditing FAQ (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional lists questions and answers about understanding, deploying, and managing security audit policies.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional lists questions and answers about understanding, deploying, and managing security audit policies.

segment.source: Advanced security auditing FAQ
segment.target: Advanced security auditing FAQ

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional lists questions and answers about understanding, deploying, and managing security audit policies.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional lists questions and answers about understanding, deploying, and managing security audit policies.

segment.source: What is Windows security auditing and why might I want to use it?
segment.target: What is Windows security auditing and why might I want to use it?

segment.source: Security auditing is a methodical examination and review of activities that may affect the security of a system.
segment.target: Security auditing is a methodical examination and review of activities that may affect the security of a system.

segment.source: In the Windows operating systems, security auditing is more narrowly defined as the features and services that enable an administrator to log and review events for specified security-related activities.
segment.target: In the Windows operating systems, security auditing is more narrowly defined as the features and services that enable an administrator to log and review events for specified security-related activities.

segment.source: Hundreds of events occur as the Windows operating system and the applications that run on it perform their tasks.
segment.target: Hundreds of events occur as the Windows operating system and the applications that run on it perform their tasks.

segment.source: Monitoring these events can provide valuable information to help administrators troubleshoot and investigate security-related activities.
segment.target: Monitoring these events can provide valuable information to help administrators troubleshoot and investigate security-related activities.

segment.source: What is the difference between audit policies located in Local PoliciesAudit Policy and audit policies located in Advanced Audit Policy Configuration?
segment.target: What is the difference between audit policies located in Local PoliciesAudit Policy and audit policies located in Advanced Audit Policy Configuration?

segment.source: The basic security audit policy settings in Security SettingsLocal PoliciesAudit Policy and the advanced security audit policy settings in Security SettingsAdvanced Audit Policy ConfigurationSystem Audit Policies appear to overlap, but they are recorded and applied differently.
segment.target: The basic security audit policy settings in Security SettingsLocal PoliciesAudit Policy and the advanced security audit policy settings in Security SettingsAdvanced Audit Policy ConfigurationSystem Audit Policies appear to overlap, but they are recorded and applied differently.

segment.source: When you apply basic audit policy settings to the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc), you are editing the effective audit policy, so changes made to basic audit policy settings will appear exactly as configured in Auditpol.exe.
segment.target: When you apply basic audit policy settings to the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc), you are editing the effective audit policy, so changes made to basic audit policy settings will appear exactly as configured in Auditpol.exe.

segment.source: There are a number of additional differences between the security audit policy settings in these two locations.
segment.target: There are a number of additional differences between the security audit policy settings in these two locations.

segment.source: There are nine basic audit policy settings under Security SettingsLocal PoliciesAudit Policy and settings under Advanced Audit Policy Configuration.
segment.target: There are nine basic audit policy settings under Security SettingsLocal PoliciesAudit Policy and settings under Advanced Audit Policy Configuration.

segment.source: The settings available in Security SettingsAdvanced Audit Policy Configuration address similar issues as the nine basic settings in Local PoliciesAudit Policy, but they allow administrators to be more selective in the number and types of events to audit.
segment.target: The settings available in Security SettingsAdvanced Audit Policy Configuration address similar issues as the nine basic settings in Local PoliciesAudit Policy, but they allow administrators to be more selective in the number and types of events to audit.

segment.source: For example, the basic audit policy provides a single setting for account logon, and the advanced audit policy provides four.
segment.target: For example, the basic audit policy provides a single setting for account logon, and the advanced audit policy provides four.

segment.source: Enabling the single basic account logon setting would be the equivalent of setting all four advanced account logon settings.
segment.target: Enabling the single basic account logon setting would be the equivalent of setting all four advanced account logon settings.

segment.source: In comparison, setting a single advanced audit policy setting does not generate audit events for activities that you are not interested in tracking.
segment.target: In comparison, setting a single advanced audit policy setting does not generate audit events for activities that you are not interested in tracking.

segment.source: In addition, if you enable success auditing for the basic Audit account logon events setting, only success events will be logged for all account logon–related behaviors.
segment.target: In addition, if you enable success auditing for the basic Audit account logon events setting, only success events will be logged for all account logon–related behaviors.

segment.source: In comparison, depending on the needs of your organization, you can configure success auditing for one advanced account logon setting, failure auditing for a second advanced account logon setting, success and failure auditing for a third advanced account logon setting, or no auditing.
segment.target: In comparison, depending on the needs of your organization, you can configure success auditing for one advanced account logon setting, failure auditing for a second advanced account logon setting, success and failure auditing for a third advanced account logon setting, or no auditing.

segment.source: The nine basic settings under Security SettingsLocal PoliciesAudit Policy were introduced in Windows 2000.
segment.target: The nine basic settings under Security SettingsLocal PoliciesAudit Policy were introduced in Windows 2000.

segment.source: Therefore, they are available in all versions of Windows released since then.
segment.target: Therefore, they are available in all versions of Windows released since then.

segment.source: The advanced audit policy settings were introduced in Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: The advanced audit policy settings were introduced in Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: The advanced settings can only be used on computers running Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, and later.
segment.target: The advanced settings can only be used on computers running Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, and later.

segment.source: What is the interaction between basic audit policy settings and advanced audit policy settings?
segment.target: What is the interaction between basic audit policy settings and advanced audit policy settings?

segment.source: Basic audit policy settings are not compatible with advanced audit policy settings that are applied by using Group Policy.
segment.target: Basic audit policy settings are not compatible with advanced audit policy settings that are applied by using Group Policy.

segment.source: When advanced audit policy settings are applied by using Group Policy, the current computer's audit policy settings are cleared before the resulting advanced audit policy settings are applied.
segment.target: When advanced audit policy settings are applied by using Group Policy, the current computer's audit policy settings are cleared before the resulting advanced audit policy settings are applied.

segment.source: After you apply advanced audit policy settings by using Group Policy, you can only reliably set system audit policy for the computer by using the advanced audit policy settings.
segment.target: After you apply advanced audit policy settings by using Group Policy, you can only reliably set system audit policy for the computer by using the advanced audit policy settings.

segment.source: Editing and applying the advanced audit policy settings in Local Security Policy modifies the local Group Policy Object (GPO), so changes made here may not be exactly reflected in Auditpol.exe if there are policies from other domain GPOs or logon scripts.
segment.target: Editing and applying the advanced audit policy settings in Local Security Policy modifies the local Group Policy Object (GPO), so changes made here may not be exactly reflected in Auditpol.exe if there are policies from other domain GPOs or logon scripts.

segment.source: Both types of policies can be edited and applied by using domain GPOs, and these settings will override any conflicting local audit policy settings.
segment.target: Both types of policies can be edited and applied by using domain GPOs, and these settings will override any conflicting local audit policy settings.

segment.source: However, because the basic audit policy is recorded in the effective audit policy, that audit policy must be explicitly removed when a change is desired, or it will remain in the effective audit policy.
segment.target: However, because the basic audit policy is recorded in the effective audit policy, that audit policy must be explicitly removed when a change is desired, or it will remain in the effective audit policy.

segment.source: Policy changes that are applied by using local or domain Group Policy settings are reflected as soon as the new policy is applied.
segment.target: Policy changes that are applied by using local or domain Group Policy settings are reflected as soon as the new policy is applied.

segment.source: Important Whether you apply advanced audit policies by using Group Policy or by using logon scripts, do not use both the basic audit policy settings under Local PoliciesAudit Policy and the advanced settings under Security SettingsAdvanced Audit Policy Configuration.
segment.target: Important Whether you apply advanced audit policies by using Group Policy or by using logon scripts, do not use both the basic audit policy settings under Local PoliciesAudit Policy and the advanced settings under Security SettingsAdvanced Audit Policy Configuration.

segment.source: Using both advanced and basic audit policy settings can cause unexpected results in audit reporting.
segment.target: Using both advanced and basic audit policy settings can cause unexpected results in audit reporting.

segment.source: If you use Advanced Audit Policy Configuration settings or use logon scripts to apply advanced audit policies, be sure to enable the Audit: Force audit policy subcategory settings (Windows Vista or later) to override audit policy category settings policy setting under Local PoliciesSecurity Options.
segment.target: If you use Advanced Audit Policy Configuration settings or use logon scripts to apply advanced audit policies, be sure to enable the Audit: Force audit policy subcategory settings (Windows Vista or later) to override audit policy category settings policy setting under Local PoliciesSecurity Options.

segment.source: This will prevent conflicts between similar settings by forcing basic security auditing to be ignored.
segment.target: This will prevent conflicts between similar settings by forcing basic security auditing to be ignored.

segment.source: How are audit settings merged by Group Policy?
segment.target: How are audit settings merged by Group Policy?

segment.source: By default, policy options that are set in GPOs and linked to higher levels of Active Directory sites, domains, and OUs are inherited by all OUs at lower levels.
segment.target: By default, policy options that are set in GPOs and linked to higher levels of Active Directory sites, domains, and OUs are inherited by all OUs at lower levels.

segment.source: However, an inherited policy can be overridden by a GPO that is linked at a lower level.
segment.target: However, an inherited policy can be overridden by a GPO that is linked at a lower level.

segment.source: For example, you might use a domain GPO to assign an organization-wide group of audit settings, but want a certain OU to get a defined group of additional settings.
segment.target: For example, you might use a domain GPO to assign an organization-wide group of audit settings, but want a certain OU to get a defined group of additional settings.

segment.source: To accomplish this, you can link a second GPO to that specific lower-level OU.
segment.target: To accomplish this, you can link a second GPO to that specific lower-level OU.

segment.source: Therefore, a logon audit setting that is applied at the OU level will override a conflicting logon audit setting that is applied at the domain level (unless you have taken special steps to apply Group Policy loopback processing).
segment.target: Therefore, a logon audit setting that is applied at the OU level will override a conflicting logon audit setting that is applied at the domain level (unless you have taken special steps to apply Group Policy loopback processing).

segment.source: The rules that govern how Group Policy settings are applied propagate to the subcategory level of audit policy settings.
segment.target: The rules that govern how Group Policy settings are applied propagate to the subcategory level of audit policy settings.

segment.source: This means that audit policy settings configured in different GPOs will be merged if no policy settings configured at a lower level exist.
segment.target: This means that audit policy settings configured in different GPOs will be merged if no policy settings configured at a lower level exist.

segment.source: The following table illustrates this behavior.
segment.target: The following table illustrates this behavior.

segment.source: Auditing subcategory
segment.target: Auditing subcategory

segment.source: Setting configured in an OU GPO (higher priority)
segment.target: Setting configured in an OU GPO (higher priority)

segment.source: Setting configured in a domain GPO (lower priority)
segment.target: Setting configured in a domain GPO (lower priority)

segment.source: Resulting policy for the target computer
segment.target: Resulting policy for the target computer

segment.target: Detailed File Share Auditing

segment.target: Success

segment.target: Failure

segment.target: Success

segment.target: Process Creation Auditing

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.target: Success

segment.target: Disabled

segment.target: Logon Auditing

segment.source: What is the difference between an object DACL and an object SACL?
segment.target: What is the difference between an object DACL and an object SACL?

segment.source: All objects in Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), and all securable objects on a local computer or on the network, have security descriptors to help control access to the objects.
segment.target: All objects in Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), and all securable objects on a local computer or on the network, have security descriptors to help control access to the objects.

segment.source: Security descriptors include information about who owns an object, who can access it and in what way, and what types of access are audited.
segment.target: Security descriptors include information about who owns an object, who can access it and in what way, and what types of access are audited.

segment.source: Security descriptors contain the access control list (ACL) of an object, which includes all of the security permissions that apply to that object.
segment.target: Security descriptors contain the access control list (ACL) of an object, which includes all of the security permissions that apply to that object.

segment.source: An object's security descriptor can contain two types of ACLs:
segment.target: An object's security descriptor can contain two types of ACLs:

segment.source: A discretionary access control list (DACL) that identifies the users and groups who are allowed or denied access
segment.target: A discretionary access control list (DACL) that identifies the users and groups who are allowed or denied access

segment.source: A system access control list (SACL) that controls how access is audited
segment.target: A system access control list (SACL) that controls how access is audited

segment.source: The access control model that is used in Windows is administered at the object level by setting different levels of access, or permissions, to objects.
segment.target: The access control model that is used in Windows is administered at the object level by setting different levels of access, or permissions, to objects.

segment.source: If permissions are configured for an object, its security descriptor contains a DACL with security identifiers (SIDs) for the users and groups that are allowed or denied access.
segment.target: If permissions are configured for an object, its security descriptor contains a DACL with security identifiers (SIDs) for the users and groups that are allowed or denied access.

segment.source: If auditing is configured for the object, its security descriptor also contains a SACL that controls how the security subsystem audits attempts to access the object.
segment.target: If auditing is configured for the object, its security descriptor also contains a SACL that controls how the security subsystem audits attempts to access the object.

segment.source: However, auditing is not completely configured unless a SACL has been configured for an object and a corresponding Object Access audit policy setting has been configured and applied.
segment.target: However, auditing is not completely configured unless a SACL has been configured for an object and a corresponding Object Access audit policy setting has been configured and applied.

segment.source: Why are audit policies applied on a per-computer basis rather than per user?
segment.target: Why are audit policies applied on a per-computer basis rather than per user?

segment.source: In security auditing in Windows, the computer, objects on the computer, and related resources are the primary recipients of actions by clients including applications, other computers, and users.
segment.target: In security auditing in Windows, the computer, objects on the computer, and related resources are the primary recipients of actions by clients including applications, other computers, and users.

segment.source: In a security breach, malicious users can use alternate credentials to hide their identity, or malicious applications can impersonate legitimate users to perform undesired tasks.
segment.target: In a security breach, malicious users can use alternate credentials to hide their identity, or malicious applications can impersonate legitimate users to perform undesired tasks.

segment.source: Therefore, the most consistent way to apply an audit policy is to focus on the computer and the objects and resources on that computer.
segment.target: Therefore, the most consistent way to apply an audit policy is to focus on the computer and the objects and resources on that computer.

segment.source: In addition, because audit policy capabilities can vary between computers running different versions of Windows, the best way to ensure that the audit policy is applied correctly is to base these settings on the computer instead of the user.
segment.target: In addition, because audit policy capabilities can vary between computers running different versions of Windows, the best way to ensure that the audit policy is applied correctly is to base these settings on the computer instead of the user.

segment.source: However, in cases where you want audit settings to apply only to specified groups of users, you can accomplish this by configuring SACLs on the relevant objects to enable auditing for a security group that contains only the users you specify.
segment.target: However, in cases where you want audit settings to apply only to specified groups of users, you can accomplish this by configuring SACLs on the relevant objects to enable auditing for a security group that contains only the users you specify.

segment.source: For example, you can configure a SACL for a folder called Payroll Data on Accounting Server 1.
segment.target: For example, you can configure a SACL for a folder called Payroll Data on Accounting Server 1.

segment.source: This can audit attempts by members of the Payroll Processors OU to delete objects from this folder.
segment.target: This can audit attempts by members of the Payroll Processors OU to delete objects from this folder.

segment.source: The Object AccessAudit File System audit policy setting applies to Accounting Server 1, but because it requires a corresponding resource SACL, only actions by members of the Payroll Processors OU on the Payroll Data folder generates audit events.
segment.target: The Object AccessAudit File System audit policy setting applies to Accounting Server 1, but because it requires a corresponding resource SACL, only actions by members of the Payroll Processors OU on the Payroll Data folder generates audit events.

segment.source: What are the differences in auditing functionality between versions of Windows?
segment.target: What are the differences in auditing functionality between versions of Windows?

segment.source: Basic audit policy settings are available in all versions of Windows since Windows 2000, and they can be applied locally or by using Group Policy.
segment.target: Basic audit policy settings are available in all versions of Windows since Windows 2000, and they can be applied locally or by using Group Policy.

segment.source: Advanced audit policy settings were introduced in Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008, but the settings can only be applied by using logon scripts in those versions.
segment.target: Advanced audit policy settings were introduced in Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008, but the settings can only be applied by using logon scripts in those versions.

segment.source: Advanced audit policy settings, which were introduced in Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, can be configured and applied by using local and domain Group Policy settings.
segment.target: Advanced audit policy settings, which were introduced in Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, can be configured and applied by using local and domain Group Policy settings.

segment.source: Can I use advanced audit policies from a domain controller running Windows Server 2003 or Windows 2000 Server?
segment.target: Can I use advanced audit policies from a domain controller running Windows Server 2003 or Windows 2000 Server?

segment.source: To use advanced audit policy settings, your domain controller must be installed on a computer running Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Server 2003 with Service Pack 2 (SP2).
segment.target: To use advanced audit policy settings, your domain controller must be installed on a computer running Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Server 2003 with Service Pack 2 (SP2).

segment.source: Windows 2000 Server is not supported.
segment.target: Windows 2000 Server is not supported.

segment.source: What is the difference between success and failure events?
segment.target: What is the difference between success and failure events?

segment.source: Is something wrong if I get a failure audit?
segment.target: Is something wrong if I get a failure audit?

segment.source: A success audit event is triggered when a defined action, such as accessing a file share, is completed successfully.
segment.target: A success audit event is triggered when a defined action, such as accessing a file share, is completed successfully.

segment.source: A failure audit event is triggered when a defined action, such as a user logon, is not completed successfully.
segment.target: A failure audit event is triggered when a defined action, such as a user logon, is not completed successfully.

segment.source: The appearance of failure audit events in the event log does not necessarily mean that something is wrong with your system.
segment.target: The appearance of failure audit events in the event log does not necessarily mean that something is wrong with your system.

segment.source: For example, if you configure Audit Logon events, a failure event may simply mean that a user mistyped his or her password.
segment.target: For example, if you configure Audit Logon events, a failure event may simply mean that a user mistyped his or her password.

segment.source: How can I set an audit policy that affects all objects on a computer?
segment.target: How can I set an audit policy that affects all objects on a computer?

segment.source: System administrators and auditors increasingly want to verify that an auditing policy is applied to all objects on a system.
segment.target: System administrators and auditors increasingly want to verify that an auditing policy is applied to all objects on a system.

segment.source: This has been difficult to accomplish because the system access control lists (SACLs) that govern auditing are applied on a per-object basis.
segment.target: This has been difficult to accomplish because the system access control lists (SACLs) that govern auditing are applied on a per-object basis.

segment.source: Thus, to verify that an audit policy has been applied to all objects, you would have to check every object to be sure that no changes have been made—even temporarily to a single SACL.
segment.target: Thus, to verify that an audit policy has been applied to all objects, you would have to check every object to be sure that no changes have been made—even temporarily to a single SACL.

segment.source: Introduced in Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7, security auditing allows administrators to define global object access auditing policies for the entire file system or for the registry on a computer.
segment.target: Introduced in Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7, security auditing allows administrators to define global object access auditing policies for the entire file system or for the registry on a computer.

segment.source: The specified SACL is then automatically applied to every object of that type.
segment.target: The specified SACL is then automatically applied to every object of that type.

segment.source: This can be useful for verifying that all critical files, folders, and registry settings on a computer are protected, and for identifying when an issue with a system resource occurs.
segment.target: This can be useful for verifying that all critical files, folders, and registry settings on a computer are protected, and for identifying when an issue with a system resource occurs.

segment.source: If a file or folder SACL and a global object access auditing policy (or a single registry setting SACL and a global object access auditing policy) are configured on a computer, the effective SACL is derived from combining the file or folder SACL and the global object access auditing policy.
segment.target: If a file or folder SACL and a global object access auditing policy (or a single registry setting SACL and a global object access auditing policy) are configured on a computer, the effective SACL is derived from combining the file or folder SACL and the global object access auditing policy.

segment.source: This means that an audit event is generated if an activity matches either the file or folder SACL or the global object access auditing policy.
segment.target: This means that an audit event is generated if an activity matches either the file or folder SACL or the global object access auditing policy.

segment.source: How do I figure out why someone was able to access a resource?
segment.target: How do I figure out why someone was able to access a resource?

segment.source: Often it is not enough to know simply that an object such as a file or folder was accessed.
segment.target: Often it is not enough to know simply that an object such as a file or folder was accessed.

segment.source: You may also want to know why the user was able to access this resource.
segment.target: You may also want to know why the user was able to access this resource.

segment.source: You can obtain this forensic data by configuring the Audit Handle Manipulation setting with the Audit File System or with the Audit Registry audit setting.
segment.target: You can obtain this forensic data by configuring the Audit Handle Manipulation setting with the Audit File System or with the Audit Registry audit setting.

segment.source: How do I know when changes are made to access control settings, by whom, and what the changes were?
segment.target: How do I know when changes are made to access control settings, by whom, and what the changes were?

segment.source: To track access control changes on computers running Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012 Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, or Windows Server 2008, you need to enable the following settings, which track changes to DACLs:
segment.target: To track access control changes on computers running Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012 Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, or Windows Server 2008, you need to enable the following settings, which track changes to DACLs:

segment.source: Audit File System subcategory: Enable for success, failure, or success and failure
segment.target: Audit File System subcategory: Enable for success, failure, or success and failure

segment.source: Audit Authorization Policy Change setting: Enable for success, failure, or success and failure
segment.target: Audit Authorization Policy Change setting: Enable for success, failure, or success and failure

segment.source: A SACL with Write and Take ownership permissions: Apply to the object that you want to monitor
segment.target: A SACL with Write and Take ownership permissions: Apply to the object that you want to monitor

segment.source: In Windows XP and Windows Server 2003, you need to use the Audit policy change subcategory.
segment.target: In Windows XP and Windows Server 2003, you need to use the Audit policy change subcategory.

segment.source: How can I roll back security audit policies from the advanced audit policy to the basic audit policy?
segment.target: How can I roll back security audit policies from the advanced audit policy to the basic audit policy?

segment.source: Applying advanced audit policy settings replaces any comparable basic security audit policy settings.
segment.target: Applying advanced audit policy settings replaces any comparable basic security audit policy settings.

segment.source: If you subsequently change the advanced audit policy setting to Not configured, you need to complete the following steps to restore the original basic security audit policy settings:
segment.target: If you subsequently change the advanced audit policy setting to Not configured, you need to complete the following steps to restore the original basic security audit policy settings:

segment.source: Set all Advanced Audit Policy subcategories to Not configured.
segment.target: Set all Advanced Audit Policy subcategories to Not configured.

segment.source: Delete all audit.csv files from the %SYSVOL% folder on the domain controller.
segment.target: Delete all audit.csv files from the %SYSVOL% folder on the domain controller.

segment.source: Reconfigure and apply the basic audit policy settings.
segment.target: Reconfigure and apply the basic audit policy settings.

segment.source: Unless you complete all of these steps, the basic audit policy settings will not be restored.
segment.target: Unless you complete all of these steps, the basic audit policy settings will not be restored.

segment.source: How can I monitor if changes are made to audit policy settings?
segment.target: How can I monitor if changes are made to audit policy settings?

segment.source: Changes to security audit policies are critical security events.
segment.target: Changes to security audit policies are critical security events.

segment.source: You can use the Audit Audit Policy Change setting to determine if the operating system generates audit events when the following types of activities take place:
segment.target: You can use the Audit Audit Policy Change setting to determine if the operating system generates audit events when the following types of activities take place:

segment.source: Permissions and audit settings on the audit policy object are changed
segment.target: Permissions and audit settings on the audit policy object are changed

segment.source: The system audit policy is changed
segment.target: The system audit policy is changed

segment.source: Security event sources are registered or unregistered
segment.target: Security event sources are registered or unregistered

segment.source: Per-user audit settings are changed
segment.target: Per-user audit settings are changed

segment.source: The value of CrashOnAuditFail is modified
segment.target: The value of CrashOnAuditFail is modified

segment.source: Audit settings on a file or registry key are changed
segment.target: Audit settings on a file or registry key are changed

segment.source: A Special Groups list is changed
segment.target: A Special Groups list is changed

segment.source: How can I minimize the number of events that are generated?
segment.target: How can I minimize the number of events that are generated?

segment.source: Finding the right balance between auditing enough network and computer activity and auditing too little network and computer activity can be challenging.
segment.target: Finding the right balance between auditing enough network and computer activity and auditing too little network and computer activity can be challenging.

segment.source: You can achieve this balance by identifying the most important resources, critical activities, and users or groups of users.
segment.target: You can achieve this balance by identifying the most important resources, critical activities, and users or groups of users.

segment.source: Then design a security audit policy that targets these resources, activities, and users.
segment.target: Then design a security audit policy that targets these resources, activities, and users.

segment.source: Useful guidelines and recommendations for developing an effective security auditing strategy can be found in Planning and deploying advanced security audit policies.
segment.target: Useful guidelines and recommendations for developing an effective security auditing strategy can be found in Planning and deploying advanced security audit policies.

segment.source: What are the best tools to model and manage audit policies?
segment.target: What are the best tools to model and manage audit policies?

segment.source: The integration of advanced audit policy settings with domain Group Policy, introduced in Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, is designed to simplify the management and implementation of security audit policies in an organization's network.
segment.target: The integration of advanced audit policy settings with domain Group Policy, introduced in Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, is designed to simplify the management and implementation of security audit policies in an organization's network.

segment.source: As such, tools used to plan and deploy Group Policy Objects for a domain can also be used to plan and deploy security audit policies.
segment.target: As such, tools used to plan and deploy Group Policy Objects for a domain can also be used to plan and deploy security audit policies.

segment.source: On an individual computer, the Auditpol command-line tool can be used to complete a number of important audit policy–related management tasks.
segment.target: On an individual computer, the Auditpol command-line tool can be used to complete a number of important audit policy–related management tasks.

segment.source: In addition, there are a number of computer management products, such as the Audit Collection Services in the Microsoft System Center Operations Manager products, which can be used to collect and filter event data.
segment.target: In addition, there are a number of computer management products, such as the Audit Collection Services in the Microsoft System Center Operations Manager products, which can be used to collect and filter event data.

segment.source: Where can I find information about all the possible events that I might receive?
segment.target: Where can I find information about all the possible events that I might receive?

segment.source: Users who examine the security event log for the first time can be a bit overwhelmed by the number of audit events that are stored there (which can quickly number in the thousands) and by the structured information that is included for each audit event.
segment.target: Users who examine the security event log for the first time can be a bit overwhelmed by the number of audit events that are stored there (which can quickly number in the thousands) and by the structured information that is included for each audit event.

segment.source: Additional information about these events, and the settings used to generate them, can be obtained from the following resources:
segment.target: Additional information about these events, and the settings used to generate them, can be obtained from the following resources:

segment.source: Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012 Security Event Details
segment.target: Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012 Security Event Details

segment.target: Security Audit Events for Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2

segment.target: Security Audit Events for Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista
